notes: This is a funerary inscription (D.M.S. = Dis Manibus sacrum) for an infant named Baduma who lived approximately 8 months minus some days. The name Baduma appears to be of local (non-Roman) origin. The inscription contains several orthographic variations: 'vixit' written as 'BIXIS', 'octo' written as 'o(c)to', and 'dies' written as 'ZIES'. The phrase 'in pace' indicates Christian or Jewish influence. The age is given in months and days rather than years, making it impossible to convert to a single age_at_death value in years.

notes: This inscription is a dedication to deities (Apollo, Genius, Liber Pater, and Ceres Casta), not to human persons. The text contains only divine names with exclamation marks indicating vocative case (direct address in prayer/dedication). No human dedicator is explicitly named in the provided text. Apollo is the Greek/Roman god of music, poetry, and prophecy; Genius is a protective spirit; Liber Pater (Liber Patrius) is the Roman god of wine and fertility, often identified with Bacchus; Ceres Casta (Chaste Ceres) is the goddess of agriculture and grain. The brackets and question marks indicate editorial uncertainty about the restoration of the text.

notes: This is a dedication inscription to Emperor Trajan from 113 CE, erected by 64 communities and two pagi (Thuscae and Gunzuzi) at their own expense. Victor Martialis, a centurion, served as curator and prefect of these communities. The inscription commemorates Trajan's 17th year of tribunician power, his 7th imperial acclamation, and his 6th consulship.

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription (indicated by 'in pace') for a young woman who died at age 17 years, 6 months, and 3 hours. She is described as 'casta puella fidelis' (chaste faithful girl). The name structure shows Roman-local syncretism: Iulia (Roman nomen) with Ansara (likely local/indigenous cognomen), and she also bore the alternative name Honoratiana (qui et = 'who is also called'). The precise recording of age including hours is characteristic of Christian epitaphs. The text contains a spelling error: 'annis' written as 'annis(!)' instead of the expected form.

notes: This is a dedicatory inscription to Emperor Constantine the Great. The text is fragmentary with missing lines indicated by [6]. The abbreviations 'DDD nn' likely stand for 'Dominis nostris' (to our lords), and 'Augg' for 'Augustis' (to the Augusti). The dating 312-324 CE corresponds to Constantine's reign as Augustus, after his victory at the Milvian Bridge (312 CE) and before he became sole emperor (324 CE). The fragmentary nature and the use of 'SEI' (possibly part of a longer word or title) makes complete interpretation difficult. The inscription appears to be an official dedication to the emperor, possibly erected by a community or official body whose name is lost in the lacunae.

notes: This is a dedication inscription from the colony of Mactaris (modern Tunisia) to Caracalla, son of Septimius Severus. The inscription dates to 202 CE when Caracalla held his fifth tribunician power. The dedication was made by decree of the local council and at public expense (p(ecunia) p(ublica)). Septimius Severus is mentioned with his victory titles: Arabicus, Adiabenicus, and Parthicus maximus.

notes: This is an honorific inscription dedicated to Lucius Aelius Caesar, the adopted son and heir of Emperor Hadrian. The inscription was erected by decree of the local decurions. The text includes Hadrian's full titulature with his 21st tribunician power. The inscription traces the imperial lineage back through Trajan (Parthicus) to Nerva. Lucius Aelius Caesar died before Hadrian, so he never became emperor himself.

notes: This inscription appears to be a dedication to Augustus (Aug(usto?) sacrum) by members of the civitas Mactaritana. The text is fragmentary and contains a list of names, many with patronymics (f(ilius) = son of). The inscription shows a mix of Roman and local (likely Punic/Libyan) names, typical of North African inscriptions. Due to the fragmentary nature and the large number of persons (39 identified), the simplified format has been used focusing on basic identification and family relationships.

career_path.position_description: Priestess of the Punic Ceres (African cult of Ceres)

notes: This is a funerary inscription (D.M.S. = Dis Manibus sacrum) for Nonnia Primitiva, a priestess of the Punic Ceres cult. She lived 87 years, 3 months, and 7 days. The epithet 'pia felix' (pious and fortunate) is a common funerary formula. The cult of Cererum Punicarum (Punic Ceres) indicates African influence, likely from North Africa where Punic religious traditions persisted.

notes: This is a dedication to Apollo Augustus and Aesculapius Augustus for the health, victories, and safety of the Severan imperial family. The inscription mentions Septimius Severus with his full titulature including tribunician power XIII, imperator XI, consul III; his son Caracalla (Marcus Aurelius Antoninus) as co-emperor with tribunician power II and princeps iuventutis; Geta whose name was erased (damnatio memoriae); and Julia Domna as Augusta and mother of the emperors, camps, senate, and fatherland. The dating suggests this inscription was made around 204-205 CE based on the tribunician powers mentioned.

notes: This is a fragmentary inscription related to the cult of Magna Mater (Cybele), as evidenced by references to 'matris' (the Mother), 'divinae domus' (divine house), and the performance of criobolium and taurobolium rituals. The inscription dates to 222-235 CE, during the reign of Severus Alexander. Publius Valerius [---]tianus served as a priest (sacerdos) and performed the sacred rites of the cernophoria, criobolium (ram sacrifice), and taurobolium (bull sacrifice). The text is heavily fragmentary with significant portions missing.

notes: This is a fragmentary funerary inscription in verse form. The text describes the deceased's life achievements: he had children (genui feliciter), acquired substantial wealth (rem non modicam) through honest means (fraude sine ulla, quaestui minimo), was honored by his own children (meis propriis natorum et honoribus auctus), and left behind eternal fame (aeternam moriens famam claramque reliquis). The deceased is identified as Pinarius Mustulus who died at age 75 (H LXXV = hic situs est, 75 years). The inscription emphasizes his prosperity, honesty in business dealings, and the honors he received. The fragmentary nature of the text makes it difficult to extract more specific information about career or social status, though the quality of the verse inscription and the emphasis on wealth and honors suggest a person of some standing in the community.

notes: This inscription is a dedication to Cybele, the Magna Mater (Great Mother of the Gods), also known as Mater Idaea. The text reads 'M(atri) d(eum) M(atri) I(daeae) / Cybelae / Aug(ustis) s(acrum)' meaning 'Sacred to the Mother of the Gods, the Idaean Mother, Cybele, for the Augusti.' This is a religious dedication rather than a personal inscription. No individual persons are named - the dedication is made to the goddess Cybele. The term 'Aug(ustis)' (for the Augusti) indicates this dedication was made in honor of or under the authority of the imperial family, but no specific emperors are named. Since no individual persons or specific communities (legions, cities, collegia, etc.) are explicitly mentioned by name, the persons and communities arrays are empty. The inscription represents a votive or dedicatory text to a deity rather than a document recording human relationships, careers, or benefactions.

notes: This is a dedication to Apollo Patrius Augustus by Tiberius Plautius Felix Ferruntianus, an equestrian officer with an extensive military career. The inscription details his service as prefect of a cavalry unit, procurator, military tribune, and commander of various detachments in Scythia, Taurica, and among the Marcomanni. He was decorated with military honors (donatus donis milit[aribus]). The text contains erasures (‚ü¶‚üß) at the end, likely indicating damnatio memoriae or later modifications. The inscription demonstrates a typical equestrian military career path in the Roman imperial period.

notes: This is a dedication inscription by Sextus Iulius Possessor, an imperial procurator, who dedicates a statue of Diana Augusta with detailed legal stipulations regarding its preservation, maintenance, and handling. The inscription specifies that the statue should not be moved from its location, should only be touched by those responsible for its care and cleaning, and requires the chief priest of Apollo's priesthood to grant permission for any necessary repairs. The text is fragmentary in several places, particularly at the end.

notes: This is a dedication to Emperor Trajan by the proconsul Caecilius Faustinus. The inscription dates to 116 CE, during Trajan's 20th year of tribunician power. The dedication was made by decree of the local decurions with public money. Trajan is identified as the son of the deified Nerva (his adoptive father) and holds the titles Germanicus and Parthicus, reflecting his military victories.

notes: This is a dedication to Emperor Antoninus Pius dated to 157 CE (based on his 20th tribunician power). The inscription is fragmentary, particularly in the lower portion where the dedicator's name is partially preserved. The dedicator appears to have made this dedication in honor of receiving a prefecture. The emperor's full titulature and genealogy (including his adoptive father Hadrian and ancestors Trajan and Nerva) are preserved in the upper portion.

notes: This is a dedication inscription for the health and victories of Emperor Septimius Severus. The text includes his imperial titles (Arabicus, Adiabenicus) and traces his adoptive lineage back to the deified emperors Trajan and Nerva. The inscription is fragmentary with significant restorations indicated by brackets. The word 'Invic[ti' at the end likely refers to Severus as 'Invictus' (unconquered).

notes: This is a Tetrarchic inscription from the reign of Diocletian and Maximian as Augusti, with Constantius Chlorus and Galerius as Caesars (293-305 CE). The inscription records a dedication made by the proconsul of Africa, Aurelius Aristobulus, at the insistence of his legate Macrinus Sossianus, with Rupilius Pisonianus managing the affair on behalf of the local community. The text emphasizes the virtues and providence of the Tetrarchs in reforming all things for the better.

notes: This is an honorific inscription dedicated to Quintus Rupilius Honoratus by his client Lucius Popilius Saturninus. Honoratus was enrolled into the equestrian order by the emperor Severus Alexander (referred to as 'divus Alexander', indicating the inscription was made after Alexander's death and deification in 235 CE). He served as a perpetual flamen, a local priest of the imperial cult. The inscription emphasizes the patron-client relationship between Honoratus and Saturninus.

benefactions.notes: Built for himself and his descendants; sponte tribuit muneri indicates voluntary dedication as a gift

notes: This is a funerary inscription. Iulius Maximus is identified as the builder (conditor) of this work (opus), which he dedicated for himself and his descendants (sibi suisque posteris). The phrase 'sponte tribuit muneri' indicates he voluntarily offered this as a gift/duty. The final clause 'ut semper Manes securum habitarent locum' expresses the purpose: so that the Manes (spirits of the dead) would always have a secure resting place. The inscription is fragmentary, with text restored in brackets.

person_relationships.notes: Son is the dedicatee of the memorial inscription

notes: This is a funerary inscription erected by a father for his son, Gaius Iulius Proculus Fortunatianus, who died at age 22. The inscription praises the son's virtues and accomplishments at different life stages: as a boy (puer) he showed excellent examples of good living, as a youth entering puberty (pubertatis initia) he showed a youthful spirit, and as a young man (iuvenis) he achieved great glory. He is described as having been intellectually strong as a boy, modest as a youth, and an orator as a young man. He delighted public audiences with his studies while wearing the toga. The inscription emphasizes that he lived a full life in a short time, accomplishing what would take many years. The Parcae (Fates) are mentioned as having predetermined his 22 years of life. The father states he restored/returned the memorial title that had been taken from him (sibi erepto reddidit). The inscription ends noting the son now rests in perpetual peace, grateful in spirit to his creator/founder (father).

person_relationships.notes: Iulius Maximus dedicated this funerary monument to Pallia Saturnina
Iulius Maximus is the dedicator of the monument

notes: This is a funerary inscription dedicated by Iulius Maximus to his deceased wife Pallia Saturnina. The inscription praises her virtues: she lived with her husband for 30 years, was devoted to her household, was religious toward her husband, modest in herself, and acted as a mother to the household. She lived with a simple spirit, barely claiming feminine adornment for herself, adorning herself with her character rather than physical appearance. The inscription emphasizes her domestic virtues and her role as a devoted wife and household manager.

person_relationships.property_text: et frater cum V[3] virgo bis denis morata orbibus
person_relationships.notes: The brother is one of the dedicators for Mosva

notes: This is a fragmentary funerary inscription. The text is heavily damaged with multiple lacunae indicated by [3]. The inscription commemorates a virgin named Mosva who died at age 20 (bis denis morata orbibus = lived through twice ten cycles/years). The inscription was erected by a flamen (local priest) and his brother. The phrase 'quod semper optavit sibi' suggests the flaminate was something the deceased or the flamen had always desired. The phrase 'eum vicit obsequio priore' is unclear but may refer to surpassing someone in devotion or service.

notes: This is a funerary inscription (Dis Manibus sacrum) for Sempronius Saturninus who died at age 45. The inscription appears on two parts, with the first part recording Saturninus' death and burial (hic situs est), and the second part identifying the dedicator.

notes: This is a funerary inscription for Lucius Victrius Polybius, a freedman who died at age 25. The inscription identifies him as the libertus (freedman) of Lucius Victrius, from whom he inherited his praenomen and nomen. The cognomen Polybius is Greek in origin, typical for freedmen who often retained their original slave names as cognomina. The epithet 'pius' suggests he was considered dutiful or devoted.

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription (indicated by 'in pace'). The deceased, Flavius Argutio, lived 30 years, 1 month, and 24 days. The inscription contains several orthographic variations typical of late antique epigraphy: 'Flavius' written with B instead of V, 'vixit' written as 'bixit', 'uno' written as 'vno' with V instead of U, and 'diebus' abbreviated as 'die' with the ending in parentheses.

The phrase 'fidelis in pace' is a common Christian formula indicating the deceased was a faithful Christian who died in peace.

notes: This is a fragmentary funerary inscription with significant text loss (indicated by [3] for missing sections). The main subject (person_id 0) appears to be deceased and speaks in first person about being freed from bodily burdens and finding peace. The text mentions 'solvi lib[enter corp]us in patrio solo' (I have freed my body in my native soil), 'meritis [onustus(?) et sol]utus taedio' (burdened with merits and freed from weariness), and 'pa]cem q[uietam ia]m dego et timeo nihil' (I now enjoy quiet peace and fear nothing). A second person, Iucustio, is mentioned near the end with the descriptor 'colonicus' (possibly a tenant farmer or colonist). The fragmentary nature makes it difficult to determine the exact relationship between the persons or extract complete information about social status, career, or benefactions. The inscription appears to be poetic or philosophical in nature, discussing mortality and peace after death.

notes: This inscription records the restoration of baths belonging to the Mactaritani, dedicated for the welfare of Emperor Marcus Aurelius. The work was carried out during the proconsulship of Sextus Lateranus (c.v.) by L. Rupilius. The dating corresponds to 170-171 CE based on Marcus Aurelius' 24th tribunician power. The text is fragmentary, particularly at the end where L. Rupilius' full name and possible titles are lost.

notes: This inscription honors Publius Septimius Geta, son of Septimius Severus and brother of Caracalla. The text shows evidence of damnatio memoriae (erasure) indicated by the double brackets ‚ü¶‚üß around Geta's name and titles, as well as references to his relationship to his father and brother. This erasure occurred after Geta was murdered by Caracalla in 211 CE. The inscription was erected by the colony of Aelia Aurelia Mactaris (modern Makthar in Tunisia) by decree of the decurions using public funds. The dating can be established to 198-199 CE based on Septimius Severus' 7th tribunician power and Caracalla's 2nd tribunician power.

notes: The inscription is highly fragmentary with only partial text preserved. The name 'Antonini' appears twice in genitive case, suggesting either multiple references to the same person or possibly multiple persons named Antoninus. The fragmentary nature makes it impossible to determine the exact context, whether this refers to an emperor (such as Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius Antoninus/Caracalla, or Elagabalus Antoninus) or a private individual. Without additional context such as imperial titles (Augustus, Caesar) or other identifying information, no confident identification with a specific emperor can be made. The genitive case suggests the person(s) is/are being referenced in relation to something else (dedication, ownership, etc.), but the fragmentary state prevents further analysis.

notes: This is a dedication inscription to Constantine as Caesar (nobilissimus Caesar) by the colony of Aelia Aurelia Augusta Mactaris. The dedication was made by decree of the decurions (d.d.) with public funds (p.p.). The inscription honors Constantine's numen and maiestas. The dating suggests this was erected during Constantine's time as Caesar, likely between 306-309 CE before he became Augustus.

notes: This is a fragmentary honorific inscription from Mactaris honoring two persons: a senator of consular rank (person 0) and his son, an equestrian (person 1). The inscription was erected by the council and people of Mactaris. The emperor's name has been erased (indicated by ‚ü¶‚üß), suggesting damnatio memoriae. Person 0 had an extensive career including positions as decemvir, aedile, juridical legate, provincial governor, and prefect of the treasury. Person 1 held the position of decemvir and was honored for his father's merits and his own good conduct toward his fellow citizens.

notes: This is an honorific inscription erected by a municipality for Marcus Valerius Quadratus, who served as their patron. The inscription was set up by decree of the decurions (d.d.) at public expense (p.p.). The career path shows the cursus honorum of a young man entering the senatorial order: vigintivir, military tribune with broad stripe, and quaestor Augusti. The dating 148-152 CE places this in the reign of Antoninus Pius. The father's name is abbreviated as M(arcus), indicating Marcus Valerius Quadratus was the son of a Marcus.

notes: This inscription honors Gaius Sextius Martialis, an equestrian who had a distinguished career in military and imperial administration. In memory of his deceased brother Titus Sextius Alexander, he donated 50,000 sesterces to his home colony of Mactaritana and established an annual feast for the decurions on his brother's birthday, funded by the interest from this donation. In recognition of his generosity, the entire curia erected a statue to him by decree of the decurions at their own expense.

notes: This is a composite inscription containing three separate funerary texts. The main text is a lengthy verse epitaph describing the life of a harvester who rose from poverty to become a leader of harvesting teams and eventually a member of the local council and censor. The text mentions work in the fields of Cirta and throughout Numidia. Two shorter epitaphs follow for C. Mulceius Maximus (died age 30) and S. Aurelius F[...]nus (died age 40). The main subject's name is partially preserved as [...]lianus, and he was married to or associated with Caeselia Namina.

notes: This inscription contains multiple funerary texts, likely from a family tomb. The first section commemorates Canneia Optata who lived 60 years. The second section is for Gaius Cassius, son of Gaius, a public defender who lived 114 years and erected the monument at his own expense. It includes a curse formula against tomb violators ('qui me commusserit habebit deos iratos et vivus ardebit'). The third section commemorates Quadratianus, also a public defender and son of a public defender, who lived 34 years. The fourth fragmentary section appears to commemorate a Cassia who lived at least 10 years. The name 'Imi[3]' after C. Cassius C. f. is unclear and may be part of a cognomen or location.

notes: This is a funerary inscription with a poetic or philosophical tone. The text states: 'Whatever good fortune can bestow upon a man from his ancestors, all these goods I brought to you, young man who died with praise.' The speaker (ego) is addressing a deceased young man, but the identity of the speaker is unclear - it could be Fortune personified, a parent, or another figure. The young man is praised for dying 'cum laude' (with honor/praise). No specific name, career, or other biographical details are provided for the deceased.

notes: Á¢ëÊñá„ÉÜ„Ç≠„Çπ„Éà„ÅåÂ≠òÂú®„Åó„Åæ„Åõ„Çì

This is a fragmentary dedication inscription to Galerius Valerius Maximianus, one of the Caesars (junior emperors) in the Tetrarchy system established by Diocletian. The dating 293-305 CE corresponds to Galerius's period as Caesar (293-305 CE) before he became Augustus. The inscription begins with 'D[D(ominis?)' which likely refers to the domini (lords/masters), a common formula in Tetrarchic inscriptions. The title 'nobb(ilissimis) Caes[s(aribus)]' (most noble Caesars) indicates this was a dedication to the Caesars, with Galerius being the one explicitly named in the surviving text. The fragmentary nature of the inscription suggests there may have been other names (possibly Constantius Chlorus, the other Caesar of the period) in the lost portions.

notes: This inscription records a dedication to the Genius of the vicus and to the vicinal deities (vicinalibus), made by Publius Geminius Saturninus in fulfillment of a promise (ex promisso) made by Sempronius Saturninus. The dedication was overseen by two curators: Publius Geminius Martialis and Crituo. The relationship between Sempronius Saturninus and Publius Geminius Saturninus is unclear - they may be related (possibly father-son given the shared cognomen Saturninus) or Publius may be acting as executor of Sempronius's promise.

notes: This inscription records two related dedications: (1) A list of members of the corpus fullonum (fullers' guild) who contributed to a building, and (2) A dedication by Sextus Nonius Iuvenalis of a statue of Liber Augustus pouring wine, made in his own name and that of his sons Nonius and Lucius. The inscription demonstrates the collective action of a professional guild and individual piety toward the imperial cult.

notes: This is a dedication to Magna Mater (Cybele) made for the health of Emperor Probus by Quintus Arellius Optatianus, a Roman equestrian and priest. The inscription records that he completed the rites of criobolium and taurobolium at his own expense, was approved as high priest (antistes) by the vote of the local council of Mactaris, and received the priesthood from Rannius Salvius (equestrian and pontiff) and Claudius Faustus (priest), together with all the dendrophori and consecrated persons of both sexes. The name of Probus has been erased (damnatio memoriae), indicated by the brackets ‚ü¶Probi‚üß.

Claudius Bonus transmitted the priesthood to Quintus Minthonius Fortunatus

notes: This inscription records a dedication to Magna Mater (Cybele) made by Quintus Minthonius Fortunatus, a priest who performed criobolium and taurobolium rituals at his own expense. The dedication was made for the health of the emperors Diocletian and Maximian and their divine house. The names of both emperors have been erased (damnatio memoriae), indicated by the double brackets. Fortunatus was approved by the local council of Mactaris and performed the rituals together with the dendrophori (tree-bearers) and other consecrated persons. The priesthood was transmitted to him by Claudius Bonus. The inscription dates to the joint reign of Diocletian and Maximian (286-305 CE).

communities.community_description: Local senate or council of decurions

notes: This is a dedication to Neptune Augustus made by public decree of the decurions and funded by public money. The inscription records a public dedication to the deity Neptune in his Augustan form (associated with the imperial cult). The abbreviation 'd(ecreto) d(ecurionum) p(ecunia) p(ublica)' indicates this was an official act of the local government, authorized by decree of the town council and paid for from public funds. No individual persons are named in this inscription - it represents a collective civic action. The community of decurions (ordo decurionum) is the authorizing body.

original_data.inscription_interpretive_cleaning: Neptuno Augusto sacrum decreto decurionum pecunia publica

communities.community_description: Association of the four public tax collectors of Africa

person_relationships.notes: Menophilus is a slave belonging to the association of the four public tax collectors of Africa

notes: This is a votive inscription to Venus. Menophilus, a slave of the association of the four public tax collectors of Africa (sociorum IIII publicorum Africae), fulfilled a vow willingly and deservedly (votum solvit libens merito). The 'socii IIII publicorum Africae' refers to a tax-farming association (societas publicanorum) that collected public revenues in the province of Africa.

notes: This is a votive dedication to Venus Augusta made by Terentia, a priestess, for the health and safety of the imperial family: Septimius Severus, Caracalla, and Iulia Domna. The inscription includes an erased section (‚ü¶6‚üß and ‚ü¶C(a)esaris‚üß), likely referring to Geta, Caracalla's brother, whose memory was condemned (damnatio memoriae) after his murder in 211 CE. The dedication was fulfilled willingly and deservedly (v.s.l.m.).

notes: This is a fragmentary inscription mentioning Felix, a Roman equestrian (eques Romanus), who made some kind of formal declaration (professio) before the ordo (local senate) of his colony, Mactaris (in North Africa, modern Tunisia). The text mentions 'domus eorum' (their house/household) and references to suffragium (voting/support) and other fragmentary names. The inscription is too fragmentary to determine the full context, but it appears to be related to some official procedure or honor involving Felix and the local government of Mactaris.

person_relationships.notes: Arruntia Sperata is the dedicatee of the monument erected by her father

notes: Funerary inscription for Arruntia Sperata, daughter of a veteran named Arruntius. She died at age 28. Her father erected a stone monument for her, with the traditional formula 'sit tibi terra levis' (may the earth be light upon you). The father expresses that he hoped she would do this for him ('quod ego speravi te mi facere'), suggesting she died before him.

notes: This is an honorary inscription for Licinia Antulla, daughter of Quintus, erected by Marcus Minthonius Tertullus. The inscription was authorized by decree of the decurions (ex decreto decurionum) and funded with public money (pecunia publica). The inscription represents a public honor granted to a woman, which was relatively uncommon and suggests she or her family held significant status in the community.

notes: Funerary inscription dedicated to the Manes (Di Manes). The main subject is a male magistrate whose name is partially lost, member of the Papiria tribe with the cognomen Tiprunitanus. He held the position of praefectus iure dicundo pro duumviro, a local magistracy with judicial authority. His wife Pomponia Saturnina, daughter of Lucius, is also commemorated; she died at age 52 and is described as pia (dutiful/pious).

The cognomen 'Salaga' appears to be of local (possibly Celtic or Iberian) origin, suggesting the person is a Roman citizen with indigenous ancestry.

notes: This is a funerary inscription dedicated to the Manes (D(is) M(anibus) s(acrum)). The deceased, Iulius Syrus Tittalus, lived 25 years, 1 month, and 11 days. The numeral 'ZV' is an unusual form representing 25 (likely a variant or error for XXV). The name structure suggests a Roman citizen (nomen Iulius) with Greek/Eastern and local cognomina (Syrus, Tittalus), indicating mixed cultural background. The inscription contains an orthographic error: 'Sy<ri=IR>us' where 'IR' was written instead of 'RI'.

Lucius Pomponius Donatus erected the monument for the memory of Iulia Saturnina

notes: This is a funerary inscription dedicated to the memory of three deceased persons: Pomponia Romana (aged 35), Marcus Tadius Rogatus (aged 70), and Iulia Saturnina (aged 11). The monument was erected by Lucius Pomponius Donatus for his most devoted parents (piissimis parentibus) and presumably his sister, for the preservation of their memory. The shared nomen 'Pomponius' between Pomponia Romana and Lucius Pomponius Donatus suggests a family connection, while Marcus Tadius Rogatus has a different nomen, possibly indicating he was the father. Iulia Saturnina, who died young at age 11, appears to be another family member, likely a daughter or sister.

person_relationships.notes: Marcus Gargilius is the dedicator who erected the monument for his family members and himself

notes: This is a funerary inscription commemorating multiple family members. Marcus Gargilius Fortunatus erected a family tomb for his parents (Selicia Saturnina and Vestali[---]), his brother, his spouse, himself, and his children and their descendants. The inscription records ages at death for several individuals: Selicia lived approximately 53 years, Vestali[---] lived 71 years, and one person (possibly the brother) lived 15 years. The monument was constructed at Marcus Gargilius's own expense (sua pecunia).

The phrase 'vixit in pace' (lived in peace) is common in Christian epitaphs.

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription (indicated by 'in pace requievit'). The deceased, Tyranus, is described as 'fidelis' (faithful), a term commonly used for Christians. The inscription provides detailed information about his age at death: 35 years, 4 months, 13 days, and 15 hours. The text contains some irregularities: 'annis' instead of the expected 'annos' or 'annorum', and uncertainty about the reading of 'triginta' (thirty). The formula 'D(is) M(anibus) s(acrum)' at the beginning is a traditional pagan dedication, but its use alongside Christian terminology ('fidelis', 'in pace') reflects the transitional period of late antiquity when Christian and pagan funerary formulas were sometimes mixed.

notes: This is an honorific inscription for Gaius Bruttius Praesens, a distinguished senator who held numerous high offices including consul and proconsul of Africa. The inscription details his extensive cursus honorum, including military commands, provincial governorships, and priesthoods. He received military decorations from both Trajan (for the Parthian War) and an unnamed Augustus (for the Marcomannic War). The inscription was set up by decree of the decurions (d.d.), indicating he was patron of the community. Lucius Fulvius Rusticus is mentioned as his consular colleague.

person_relationships.notes: Innocentia lived an innocent life with her spouse

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription for Innocentia, who lived an innocent life with her spouse. The text mentions she now resides in the Elysian fields (Elyseos campos). The inscription references Roman fate (Romanaq(ue) fata) and Italian land (Itala tellus). She died on the Kalends of May during the consulship of Flavius [name lost], dated between 414-454 CE. The age at death was recorded but the number is not preserved in the fragmentary text. The inscription shows Christian influence with the phrase 'in pace' (in peace).

notes: Christian funerary inscription. Constantinus died at age 64 years and 8 months. The inscription emphasizes his Christian faith ('tropeo fidei vincens', 'cum Chr(ist)o fidelis per s(a)ecula regnaturus'). Death date: 13 days before the Kalends of May, indiction 14. The phrase 'rabiem inimicorum tropeo fidei vincens' suggests he overcame the rage of enemies through the trophy of faith.

person_relationships.notes: The daughter erected the memorial and bids farewell to Honorata

notes: This is a funerary inscription for Honorata, who died at age 8 (bis quaternos = 2x4 = 8 years). The inscription was erected by her daughter, who bids farewell. The text is poetic and emotional, with the daughter addressing the deceased. The date of deposition is given as the 8th day before the Ides of April (April 6th) in the 14th indiction. The inscription contains several orthographic variations: qua<n=M>ta (quanta), <h=TI>os (hos), <v=B>aledictura (valedictura), octa<v=B>u(m) (octavum), April<e=I>s (Apriles).

persons.age_at_death_evidence: vixit in pace pl(us) m(inus) annis XXX

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription for a woman named Benenata, also known as Iambaria. She is described as 'castimonialis', which refers to a woman who has taken a vow of chastity or a consecrated virgin in early Christian communities. The inscription is dated to the 12th day before the Kalends of December (November 20) in the 11th indiction. She lived approximately 30 years (plus or minus). The phrase 'vixit in pace' is a typical Christian formula. The double name 'quae et' (also called) suggests she may have had both a local/indigenous name and a Christian name, or two names from different cultural contexts.

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription with classical mythological references. The deceased, Iulia Mo(?) Benenata, is described as an 'honesta femina' (honorable woman) who lived 83 years and 10 months. The poetic text describes her virtuous life and her journey to the afterlife, mentioning the Elysian fields and Proserpina's domains. The inscription combines Christian elements ('in pace') with classical underworld imagery (Acheron, Acherusian temples). The abbreviation 'Mo()' in her name is unclear and may represent a second cognomen or other name element. The inscription ends with the standard funerary formula 'h(ic) s(ita) e(st)' (here she is laid).

communities.community_description: Ancient Rome

notes: This is a Christian funerary inscription with complex poetic language. The text appears to be a mixture of funerary formula (D.M.S.) and Christian content. The deceased died at age 15 years, 5 months, and 30 days (per lustra ann. III = 3 lustra = 15 years). The inscription mentions 'pater optime mundi' (best father of the world), likely referring to God rather than a human father. 'Roma antiqua' is mentioned but in a context that suggests the deceased did not desire worldly things ('non Privata cupit Roma antiqua'). The phrase 'redde domos sanctas' (return the holy homes) and 'transire para Ch(ristum)' (prepare to pass through Christ) indicate Christian content. The name of the deceased is not preserved in the inscription.

notes: This is a funerary inscription for Cela, a female slave (ancilla). The inscription combines pagan and Christian elements: 'D(is) M(anibus) s(acrum)' (sacred to the spirits of the dead - pagan formula) alongside 'deus sanctus' (holy god - Christian reference) and 'in pace' (in peace - Christian formula). The text mentions she lived the years that fate and god decreed for her, but does not specify the exact number. The inscription also mentions she now holds an eternal seat and her spouse (later iugali) suffers deep sleep without end. The text contains orthographic variations: 'vi{c}xit' for 'vixit', 'decre<v=B>it' for 'decrevit', 'nu(n)c' for 'nunc', '(a)eterna(m)' for 'aeternam', 'lateriq(ue)' for 'laterique'. The reference to 'later iugali' (spouse/marriage partner) suggests she was married, though the spouse is not named in the inscription.

The age at death is partially preserved but incomplete: '[vi]xit an(nos) [3] m(enses) [' indicates the person lived for an unknown number of years and months. The exact numbers are lost in the lacunae. The exclamation mark (!) in the transcription likely indicates an error or unusual spelling in 'requie' for 'requiescit'.

notes: This inscription records the dedication of a bronze statue to Apollo Patrius Augustus by Sextus Iulius Possessor, an equestrian official with an extensive career in military commands and imperial procuratorships. The statue was brought from overseas. His adlection into the decuriae was authorized by the emperors Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus) and Lucius Verus, dating the inscription to their joint reign (161-169 CE), though the inscription dating extends to 171-200 CE, suggesting the dedication occurred after Verus's death in 169 CE.

notes: This inscription commemorates a dedication made by Quintus Licinius Aurintius Victorinus, curator of the community, together with the splendid council. The dedication was made during the ninth consulship of Constantius II (as Augustus) and the second consulship of Julian (as Caesar), which dates the inscription to 357 CE. The phrase 'Saeculi felicitate' refers to the happiness/prosperity of the age under the emperors' rule.

notes: The inscription is highly fragmentary with significant text loss indicated by [3] (three missing characters). The text appears to contain 'NAE LI[3]' (possibly part of a name or dedication), 'sacrum' (indicating a sacred dedication), and 'criobo[lium(?)' (possibly criobolium, a ritual sacrifice associated with Magna Mater cult). Due to the fragmentary nature, no complete personal names, communities, or relationships can be reliably extracted. The term 'criobolium' if correctly restored would indicate a religious context related to the cult of Cybele/Magna Mater, but this remains uncertain. The dating of 1-300 CE is broad and does not help narrow down specific identifications.

notes: This is a fragmentary dedication to Caesar Augustus. The inscription indicates that Roman citizens (cives Romani) and the civic community (civitas) jointly financed and erected this monument (p(ecunia) s(ua) f(aciundum) c(uraverunt) = 'took care to have it made at their own expense'). The specific emperor cannot be definitively identified from the fragmentary text alone, but 'Augustus' is used as the default normalized form for the imperial title. The inscription follows a common formula for civic dedications to emperors.

notes: Fragmentary funerary inscription. The text is heavily damaged with significant portions missing (indicated by [3]). The inscription mentions a deceased person (person 0) whose name is partially preserved as '[...]sior Imconis', and identifies their father (person 1) as '[...]tini Spuri filius' (son of Spurius). The formula 'vixit' indicates this is a funerary inscription. The abbreviation 'h(ic) s(itus?)' likely stands for 'hic situs (est)' meaning 'here lies'. The praenomen Spurius (abbreviated S.) is relatively rare in Roman nomenclature.

notes: This is a funerary inscription for a young woman named Beccut who died at age 15. The text is poetic and describes her marriage to Ilo, her death shortly after, and her role as a mother. The inscription mentions she was a virgin bride (virgo rudis) who became a mother with the favor of Lucina (goddess of childbirth). There appear to be two separate inscriptions or sections: one for Beccut and another fragmentary one mentioning [...]L[...]eia who also died at age 15, and a third person named Euthesia. The relationship between these persons is unclear from the fragmentary text.

persons.social_status_evidence: fandi quondam vitaeq(ue) magister semper fide a<t=D>q(ue) salutiferas curas humanis debebat corporibus
persons.ethnicity_evidence: tria nomina structure: Aulus Lurius Geminius

notes: This is a funerary inscription for Aulus Lurius Geminius, a physician (medicus). The text describes him as a 'master of speech and life' (fandi quondam vitaeq(ue) magister) who provided healing care to human bodies (salutiferas curas humanis debebat corporibus). He lived for 80 years, completing 80 great cycles of months (LXXX enim magnos <v=B>olvendis mensibus orbes). The inscription contains several orthographic variations: a<t=D>q(ue) for atque, and <v=B>olvendis and quie<v=B>it where V is written as B. The phrase 'fidelis vitam peregit consequentibus metis' indicates he lived a faithful life following his goals/limits. He rests in peace in this worthy place (hac sede digna in pace quie<v=B>it).

notes: This is a fragmentary funerary inscription in verse form. The deceased (gender male based on verb forms) speaks in first person about his life achievements: he lived sufficiently, had children successfully, accumulated considerable wealth from small beginnings without fraud, enhanced his own and his children's honors through his own resources, and left behind eternal and illustrious fame upon death. The text emphasizes honest business practices ('fraude sine ulla'), self-made success ('e minimo quaestu'), and family legacy ('natorum honoribus'). No specific name, career positions, or communities are preserved in the extant fragment.
